incident_updates.body: We have continued to see good performance for requests using Slam-1 and are now marking this issue as resolved.
Success rates and turnaround times for requests using Slam-1 have returned to normal ranges, but we are continuing to monitor traffic to ensure continued good performance.
We are still seeing good success rates for requests using the Slam-1 model, but we are still seeing occasional slower-than-usual processing times, which we are working to address.
We are once again starting to see requests using Slam-1 succeed, but we are still working to fully resolve the issue. We will follow up with another update once the issue has been fully mitigated.

We are now seeing increased error rates and failures for requests using the Slam-1 model so we are elevating this issue to a partial outage. Requests using Universal are working normally, so consider using that model as a short-term workaround if needed. Our team is working to resolve this issue as quickly as possible.

We are currently seeing longer-than-usual turnaround times for pre-recorded audio transcriptions that are using our Slam-1 model. Requests using the Universal model are unaffected. We are working to address this issue and will provide an update here as soon as possible.
This incident has been resolved.
Account creation and updates are once again working normally, but we are continuing to monitor the situation to ensure continued good performance.
We are currently experiencing an issue with new account creation due to the ongoing AWS issues that may affect the ability of newly created accounts to use our API or Playground.

incidents.name: Increased error rates for pre-recorded Speech-to-Text

incident_updates.body: We have continued to see good performance for pre-recorded audio so we are now marking this issue as resolved.
We have released a fix to address the small increase in errors we were seeing and are monitoring to ensure continued good performance.

Our team has identified where the errors are occurring in our pipeline and is currently working to identify and resolve the root cause. This issue is currently only affecting an extremely small percentage of total pre-recorded audio traffic. 99%+ of requests are still completing successfully.

Our team is currently investigating an issue that is causing an increase in server errors for our pre-recorded audio speech-to-text feature. This issue is only affecting a small number of requests, but it is affecting requests to both Universal and Slam-1 models. If you experience a server error we suggest retrying the request as those will likely be successful.

incidents.name: Some Streaming Sessions are Failing to be Established

incident_updates.body: We have continued to see good performance since rolling back the update that was identified to be the cause of this issue, so we are marking this issue as resolved.

We have continued to see stable performance throughout the day. The Streaming API is operating normally and we are monitoring the effects of recent changes to ensure continued service stability. Our team continues working to determine the root cause of the earlier connection failures.
Our team is still investigating the cause of the elevated errors, but the Streaming API is still continuing to function normally.
The Streaming API has now returned to full functionality. Our team is still investigating the root cause of this issue.

Between 1:30p and 1:40p GMT there were an increased number of new streaming sessions that were failing to be established. Customers would have received the error message "received 3005 (registered) Session Cancelled: An error occurred; ".

incidents.name: Increased Processing Time for Non-English Language Transcriptions

incident_updates.body: From 8a - 10a GMT there was an issue related to the pick-up time of our non-English language models. This caused an increase in processing time for pre-recorded transcriptions. Our Engineering team has released a fix and all transcriptions should now be processing normally.

incidents.name: Increase in turnaround times for pre-recorded audio transcription

incident_updates.body: Aside from a small window of about five minutes around 12:10pm PT where turnaround times were slightly higher than usual, we have continued to see turnaround times within the expected ranges so we are now closing this issue.

We are currently investigating an issue that is causing a small increase in turnaround times for STT services for pre-recorded audio for some requests. Traffic as a whole is still completing within the range of normal turnaround times. We will provide additional updates as we learn more.

We experienced an issue with our Streaming API between 09:00 GMT and 10:04 GMT. This resulted in reduced quality of service for streaming sessions and some sessions were closing unexpectedly. A fix was implemented and our Streaming API is now functioning normally.

We have continued to see good performance for the last ~6 hours so we are marking this issue as resolved.

We are still seeing good performance with the Slam model and requests completing as expected, but we are still working to fully resolve the root cause to prevent issues in the future.

Note: This issue is only affecting requests using Slam-1 as the `speech_model`. Changing the `speech_model` to Universal will allow requests to complete successfully. We are currently investigating an issue with Slam-1 that is preventing the successful completion of transcription requests using the model. We will share additional information as it becomes available.

Please note this issue is only affecting requests using Slam-1 as the `speech_model`. Universal is unaffected.

incidents.name: Dashboard information not updating as expected

On Tuesday, February 25th from 1:01 AM to 1:08 AM Eastern Time, our service experienced a brief disruption during a routine database maintenance. During this 7-minute window, some API requests returned 500 errors, while other transcription requests were temporarily delayed in our processing queue. Any transcripts successfully queued were automatically retried and processed by our systems. Our team quickly identified the issue, reverted the changes, and fully restored service functionality by 1:08 AM. We continue to actively monitor our Async API to ensure everything is operating normally.
We have continued to see good performance and previously affected users are reporting that the issues are resolved on their end as well so we are marking this issue as resolved.
We have released a fix aimed to address the account issues we have been experiencing and are monitoring to ensure that the issue has been resolved.

We are currently investigating an issue that is causing account information to not update correctly. This can affect some of the information displayed in the dashboard including account balance, which in some edge cases involving recent payments can affect API usage.

On January 3th, 2025 and on January 8th, 2025, we experienced two incidents that resulted in service disruptions and performance degradation for our asynchronous API.

**Root Cause Analysis**  
Increased demand for the AssemblyAI asynchronous API has required changes to our datastore infrastructure to maintain performance and reliability.

* **January 3th:** Transcription Record Service system did not scale out aggressively enough to properly service the traffic. We identified a misconfiguration in the scaling policies that constrained the service’s ability to scale out. This resulted in degraded performance for and high latency time for all requests during the 1 hour window.
* **January 8th:** Our team deployed a configuration update to our infrastructure that unexpectedly caused a redeployment of the transcription record service. This resulted in failures for all customer requests during the 20-minute window while the transcription record service was redeployed and scaled back out to handle current traffic.

While both of these incidents impacted the same service, the underlying cause of each incident was different.

**Resolution and Next Steps**  
To prevent similar incidents in the future, we have:

* Adjusted the auto-scaling rules of the Transcription Record Service to scale more aggressively with additional performance metrics
* Implemented additional pre-deployment validation checks on infrastructure code changes
* Strengthening our infrastructure configuration management processes
* Improving the communication cadence to the [status page](https://status.assemblyai.com/) throughout the incident lifecycle

**Customer Commitment**  
We apologize for any inconvenience or disruption these incidents may have caused. We are committed to providing a reliable and high-performing service and are taking steps to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. As always, you can rely on the [status page](https://status.assemblyai.com/) for up to date API information on our current status and health.
Resolving issue.

**Root Cause Analysis**  
Increased demand for the AssemblyAI asynchronous API has required changes to our datastore infrastructure to maintain performance and reliability.

* **January 3th:** Transcription Record Service system did not scale out aggressively enough to properly service the traffic. We identified a misconfiguration in the scaling policies that constrained the service’s ability to scale out. This resulted in degraded performance for and high latency time for all requests during the 1 hour window.
* **January 8th:** Our team deployed a configuration update to our infrastructure that unexpectedly caused a redeployment of the transcription record service. This resulted in failures for all customer requests during the 20-minute window while the transcription record service was redeployed and scaled back out to handle current traffic.

While both of these incidents impacted the same service, the underlying cause of each incident was different.

**Resolution and Next Steps**  
To prevent similar incidents in the future, we have:

* Adjusted the auto-scaling rules of the Transcription Record Service to scale more aggressively with additional performance metrics
* Implemented additional pre-deployment validation checks on infrastructure code changes
* Strengthening our infrastructure configuration management processes
* Improving the communication cadence to the [status page](https://status.assemblyai.com/) throughout the incident lifecycle

**Customer Commitment**

We are committed to providing a reliable and high-performing service and are taking steps to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. As always, you can rely on the [status page](https://status.assemblyai.com/) for up to date API information on our current status and health.

We are currently investigating an increase in the number of 5xx errors from LeMUR. This is currently affecting ~10% of traffic, with the majority of jobs completing successfully. If you have retry logic in your process for handling failed requests those retries are likely to succeed. Our team is currently investigating the cause of the increased error rate and we will provide further updates as we learn more.

incidents.name: Slower than normal processing times for our Async endpoint

incident_updates.body: We have continued to see processing times remain in the expected range and this issue is now being marked as resolved.

We have identified the root cause of the slowdown, which was a brief delay in how quickly additional AWS instances came online to support an increase in traffic. Processing times have returned to normal and we are monitoring traffic to ensure continued good performance.

We are currently seeing slower-than-normal turnaround times for our Async API. Our Engineering team is actively working on the issue. We will keep you posted as we work to get processing times back to normal.
